Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: To the Frontiers of Few-Nucleon Effective Field Theories
Award.AbstractNarration:
Modern Nuclear Physics rises to the challenge to understand how the complex
structure of hadrons and nuclei at low energies emerges from Quantum Chromo
Dynamics QCD, the fundamental theory of strong interactions. Effective Field
Theory, the model-independent, systematic description at low energies, has
lead to a vibrant interplay between experiment and theory.

The goal of this project is a better understanding how the internal structure
of nucleons and few-nucleon systems emerges from QCD: The heart of its
approach are model-independent estimates of its theoretical uncertainties
which in turn lead to reliable determinations of nuclear binding effects and
few-nucleon forces. Both encode essential information about QCD. I merge this novel
description with well-developed but sophisticated numerical techniques to
extend it into the realm of light nuclei. Besides the intrinsic interest, I
will investigate few-nucleon reactions which are hard, if not impossible, to measure
but essential for Astro-Physics (e.g. in big-bang nucleo-synthesis or
supernovae) and for tests of extensions of the Standard Model of Particle
Physics. Such an approach is in addition vital to compare and understand
proton and neutron properties with a minimum of theoretical prejudice. I therefore
provide model-independent parameterisations and predictions in close contact with a
variety of current and upcoming experiments. One focus is to extract the
nucleon polarisabilities, and in particular the so-far poorly explored
spin-polarisabilities, which contain essential information on the constituents
and spin-structure of the nucleon.

With research and teaching inseparable in higher education, I will train
both undergraduate and graduate students in communication and teaching skills
in a non-traditional format, enabling them to raise the general standard of
scientific literacy. Students will apply the acquired skills in GW courses for
school teachers and high-school pupils in the DC area, where the
socio-economic and educational indicators are particularly low.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to better understand the quandary of Nuclear
Physics: The internal structure of nucleons, i.e. of the constituents of the
atomic nucleus, and the forces between them is extremely rich at low energies;
but the fundamental theory of strong interactions has successfully been
explored in experiments at much higher energies. Thus, how does the complexity
of Nuclear Physics arise from a deceptively simple fundamental theory? Under
which conditions do these forces bind nucleons together into nuclei, and how?
This is also important input into understanding the Physics of the first three
minutes of our Universe, how and why supernovae explode, and what phenomena
may be found which does not fit into our present picture of Nature -- to name
just a few topics which were addressed by this award.

In this context, model-independent estimates of theoretical uncertainties are
vital to understand properties of nucleons and nuclei with a
minimum of theoretical prejudice. My group therefore provided model-independent
parametrisations, predictions and extractions in close contact with a variety
of current and upcoming experiments. Based on this, we could pinpoint which
future experiments will be most useful.

One focus was to extract the so-called nucleon polarisabilities, and in
particular the so-far poorly explored spin-polarisabilities. They contain
essential information on the constituents and spin-structure of the nucleon
and parametrise how the nucleon reacts to external electromagnetic fields. One
appended figure shows new values we obtained for two such characteristic
quantities. We now see a signal that the proton and neutron get indeed
deformed differently. This is also important to understand why the proton  and
neutron do not have the same mass. Our predictions for the rates by which
light nuclei are created during the Big Bang was confirmed experimentally (see
Figure). We also found indications that the structure of some nuclear systems
is insensitive to details of the underlying forces and hence cannot reasonably
be used to test them. Rather, it emerges from quite general, "universal"
properties. Here, we performed the first model-independent calculations of
systems with 5 and 6 nucleons. We also investigated what changes are induced
when light nuclei are squeezed into very small "boxes". To understand this is
imperative to minimise the run-times of simulations of nuclear properties which
use the fastest high-performance computers available. Finally, we studied how
to find signals of the "weak" force in Nuclear Physics. This least-explored of
all forces of Nature can be identified by comparing two experiments which are
literally mirror-images of each other.

When we work with graduate students, we educate the educators, innovators and
leaders of tomorrow. I thus addressed the gap between the knowledge they are
taught in courses on one side, and the expectations researchers, employers and
the public have on the other side. The problem is a curriculum for graduate
students in Physics which has hardly changed in form or content for more than
60 years -- down to even using the same textbooks. High drop-out rates and
long times to degree add to the mix. I have designed a new Physics Graduate
Curriculum, including an additional emphasis on developing meta-cognitive
skills, new lecture contents, new assessment tools (both formal and informal),
a shift towards interactive learning, and improvements in mentoring and
monitoring progress. The package has successfully been implemented at our
department and publicised nation-wide.
